column2: P5JS - Animated Gif Collage - Part 1
What you'll do
Let's load up some cool animated gifs as a start to our animated art piece!

Welcome, {{user_name}}! Today, we'll be learning how to make a collage out of animated GIFs. If you've never made a collage, don't worry - it's a type of art made by sticking a big collection of different things together.
p5.js has a live online editor we can use - If it doesn't open automatically, use this link: https://editor.p5js.org/

Every p5.js sketch has 2 main parts, setup() and draw() - You’ve seen these before in other p5.js activities. setup() runs once, at the beginning, and draw() runs continuously until the program is stopped.

First off, let’s make our working area a little bigger. setup() is where we create the canvas, the place where all our GIFs will show up. Right now, it’s only 400 pixels by 400 pixels. I think we need more room!
Let’s change createCanvas(400,400); to createCanvas(600,600);
If you pressed Play right now, you’d see our new, larger canvas – but we still have a lot to do. Let’s find some GIFs to use!
Open a new tab or window for your web browser, and go to http://giphy.com (or click the link!)
Search for something you want in your collage, and then click on one of those GIFs in the search results.
On the page for that GIF, click the Copy Link button, which should make a box with 3 different links pop up..
Select and copy the middle one, the “GIF Link”, then go back to the p5.js web editor.
Let’s store this GIF in our sketch so we can use it later in the code. At the very top of the sketch, before setup(), we need to create a new function.
At the very top, on line 1, type: function preload() { (press Enter twice for 2 new lines) }
There’s our new function. When we put it into another part of the program, it will do whatever we write between the curly braces ( {} ).
Of course, there’s nothing in there right now! Let’s fix that. On the blank line between the 2 curly braces ( {} ), type: gif1 = loadImage(“ (paste in the address of the GIF that you copied) ”);
So, for example, mine looks like this: gif1 = loadImage("https://media.giphy.com/media/11StaZ9Lj74oCY/giphy.gif");

Now we need to show the image. Inside the curly braces ( {} ) for the draw() function, on the line after background(..., type this: image(gif1, 0, 0); This “adds” the image to the canvas and displays it, using the name that we gave the GIF in the preload() function.
Now, if you run your code, you should see your GIF! Cool, right?
Next time, we’ll learn to do even more things with the GIFs, like play and pause them. See you then!
